references: The dataset comprises 210,000 samples, including 147,000 for training and 63,000 for testing. The dataset was collected from three distinct Ethereum mining nodes, providing a diverse and comprehensive set of data points. The data samples are categorized into five classes: one representing normal behaviour and four types of attacks (DoS, FoT, BP, and MitM attacks). The dataset includes 21 key features extracted from the blockchain network traffic as described in Table I. The features are extracted from raw network traffic to distinguish normal behaviour from attacks.

S5.T2.caption: TABLE II: The performance results of the simulations.

Recall 87.87 87.84 90.02 90.98 76.21 81.75 88.03 86.54 83.82 86.84 89.71 89.14 87.36 87 89.91 90.27

Because of the fluctuations at the end of 1,000 iterations with MA noise, the accuracy, precision, and recall are calculated by taking average values of the last 100 iterations (i.e., the average value from iteration 900 to 1000). First, it is observed that the accuracy increases proportionally to the number of clusters. However, in general, the accuracy with added noises is smaller than the accuracy without noise in all the cases as shown in Table

Because of the fluctuations at the end of 1,000 iterations with MA noise, the accuracy, precision, and recall are calculated by taking average values of the last 100 iterations (i.e., the average value from iteration 900 to 1000). However, in general, the accuracy with added noises is smaller than the accuracy without noise in all the cases as shown in Table II. Fig. 8 provides the confusion matrix for no noise, Gaussian noise, Laplace noise, and MA noise in the case of 100 clusters with <math alttext="\epsilon=0.5" class="ltx_Math" display="inline" id="S5.SS3.p4.4.m4.1">
  <semantics id="S5.SS3.p4.4.m4.1a">
    <mrow id="S5.SS3.p4.4.m4.1.1" xref="S5.SS3.p4.4.m4.1.1.cmml">
      <mi id="S5.SS3.p4.4.m4.1.1.2" xref="S5.SS3.p4.4.m4.1.1.2.cmml">ϵ</mi>
      <mo id="S5.SS3.p4.4.m4.1.1.1" xref="S5.SS3.p4.4.m4.1.1.1.cmml">=</mo>
      <mn id="S5.SS3.p4.4.m4.1.1.3" xref="S5.SS3.p4.4.m4.1.1.3.cmml">0.5</mn>
    </mrow>
    <annotation-xml encoding="MathML-Content" id="S5.SS3.p4.4.m4.1b">
      <apply id="S5.SS3.p4.4.m4.1.1.cmml" xref="S5.SS3.p4.4.m4.1.1">
        <eq id="S5.SS3.p4.4.m4.1.1.1.cmml" xref="S5.SS3.p4.4.m4.1.1.1"/>
        <ci id="S5.SS3.p4.4.m4.1.1.2.cmml" xref="S5.SS3.p4.4.m4.1.1.2">italic-ϵ</ci>
        <cn id="S5.SS3.p4.4.m4.1.1.3.cmml" type="float" xref="S5.SS3.p4.4.m4.1.1.3">0.5</cn>
      </apply>
    </annotation-xml>
    <annotation encoding="application/x-tex" id="S5.SS3.p4.4.m4.1c">\epsilon=0.5</annotation>
    <annotation encoding="application/x-llamapun" id="S5.SS3.p4.4.m4.1d">italic_ϵ = 0.5</annotation>
  </semantics>
</math>. In this figure, we can look deeply into the accuracy of each classification class. We can see that, in this case, the added noise has a strong effect on the MitM attacks that leads to the reduction of the total accuracy of the whole system. However, there is a slight increase in the accuracy of attack detection on BP attacks at 86% with Gaussian noise in comparison with 82% without noise. The reason is that, in this case, the DP parameters play a role as a regularization factor for the deep learning model to improve the accuracy of attack detection.

italic_ϵ = 0.5. In this figure, we can look deeply into the accuracy of each classification class. We can see that, in this case, the added noise has a strong effect on the MitM attacks that leads to the reduction of the total accuracy of the whole system. However, there is a slight increase in the accuracy of attack detection on BP attacks at 86% with Gaussian noise in comparison with 82% without noise. The reason is that, in this case, the DP parameters play a role as a regularization factor for the deep learning model to improve the accuracy of attack detection.

Table II describes the detailed results of the performance in accuracy, precision, and recall in the cases of 3 clusters, 10 clusters, 50 clusters and 100 clusters and <math alttext="\epsilon=0.5" class="ltx_Math" display="inline" id="S5.SS3.p4.1.m1.1">
  <semantics id="S5.SS3.p4.1.m1.1a">

Because of the fluctuations at the end of 1,000 iterations with MA noise, the accuracy, precision, and recall are calculated by taking average values of the last 100 iterations (i.e., the average value from iteration 900 to 1000). First, it is observed that the accuracy increases proportionally to the number of clusters. However, in general, the accuracy with added noises is smaller than the accuracy without noise in all the cases as shown in Table
